Journal Story: Wow! It’s getting close to lift off. Just got my flight confirmation info.
I am amazed at how much time, money, and preparation it has taken to simply put as little as possible in to a pack and go for a hike.
I’m starting a week from now and the forecast is for temps in the low 50’s and there is a 60% chance of rain. That sounds much better than the last few weeks.

Thursday 3/14/19
First day on the trail. Foggy, a sprinkle or two, 60s. Met lots of hikers on trail, ate late lunch at hawk shelter. Crowded, but folks in good spirits. I hiked on to Devils Kitchen camp site. Took advantage of decent weather and trail conditions and hike steadily today. Stopped about 5:30to set up tent and eat dinner. Around  8:15, rain, lightning and thunder started. Stunning light and sound show that seemed to be1 foot above my tent. It rained all night and shower til 11ish today.Many thanks to my brother Jim, Ann, Amy, Jeff, my brother Tim and four great dogs in NC. They fed me, got me to fuel canisters, took me on wonderful dog walks, told great stories and  drove me to Springer Mtn. Jim even hiked the first few miles with me. He drew the line at carrying the pack!

Day 2 
Showers to 11, then windy and partly cloudy the rest of the day. The trail damp, with occasional stretches of puddles from rain or little springs. The last 4 miles were up Blood Mtn and down very steep, rocky and wet trail. Made to Neil’s Gap and a gear shop and hostel called Mountain Crossing (google it if you want, the shoe tree is a hoot) stayed at the hostel. A church group graciously supplied “trail magic” barbecue pulled pork dinners and  fixens to all thru hikers. I repeatedly thanked them and professed a new found love for the great state of Georgia!

Day 3
The wind howled last night. The first hikers that stepped out of the hostel in the morning screamed and yelled, nobody wanted to follow them!
That said, after I warmed up, it was a good hiking day with more free food at a road crossing. Phenomenal food and hot coffee from Bob and Misty. I again professed my love of the people of Georgia! No leaves on the trees, so the views of surrounding mountains are great. With all the great food and descent trail conditions I was able to hike from noon to 6:30ish with no desire to stop. The shelter is on top and it was very cold. I wore everything I had, wrapped my feet with my windbreaker, hopped in the bag inside the tent and was warm all night. A guy named Turtle had a nice fire going and we had a great sunset.

Lots of sun, great views, many day hikers out enjoying too. Made it to the shelter and only 1 person was using it so I did too. Others rolled in later for a total of maybe 7 tents and 6 in the shelter. Still cold, not as windy and I didn’t sleep well at all even though I was plenty warm enough.

Made coffee, had a bit to eat and watched a great sunrise. Only 4 miles to the road crossing and I was lucky to hitch a quick ride. As soon as I started chatting with the driver, we realized we had done very similar things in our careers. Thanks for the lift Steve! I have spent all afternoon in Hiawassee doing laundry, grocery shopping, organizing and cleaning gear, took a looong hot shower in my hotel room. Oh, I have eaten several times too.By the way, if all these entries and my scattered thoughts seem confusing, well you’re right. Some I’m writing days later. Often my phone won’t work right at 25 degrees with my stone cold thumbs poking at the screen and I’m too friggin tired to figure out what the heck I’m doing wrong. But I’ll keep trying!

late start due to shuttle. Pushed to reach Standing Indian Shelter, which is high up and had fabulous sunset and sunrise. Shelter was cold, very drafty, wore 3 layers in my bag and stayed warm enough.

Tough climb up Albert Mountain (6,000 something). Fabulous views from Albert Mountain fire tower (google it). Met and hiked thru the afternoon with Nemo who completed the PCT last year. Long day to finish my first week on the trail with 105.6 miles. Only possible due to good weather and the tough work of trail maintenance crews that cleared huge amounts of downed trees. ThankYou!!!So I made it outta Georgia. Hit the 100 mile mark and completed my first week. So any of my dear family or friends that were taking bets (and given my history I don’t blame you!) that the old buzzard would end up in an emergency room before he hit NC or renounce his evil ways and join one of the church groups feeding hikers.... pay up people!

Up early for a quick 4mi to the road and a shuttle to Franklin. Cloudy, not as cold last night, crowded shelter. Currently showered, full, laundered, caffeinated and working on 2nd dessert while getting town chores done. Anticipating an upcoming visit from the A & J Resupply, renown local outfitters(Amy and Jeff)! Working on the logistics.
Destination: Winding Stair Gap with shuttle to Franklin, NC

Journal Story: long day of climbing balds, cold at start. Wind so bad at siler bald was almost knocked down . But it’s beautiful to be bald, great views!First night completely alone away from shelters or camp sites. Way up on narrow ridge, little wind, fab sunset/sunrise.
Start location: Winding Stair Gap with shuttle to Franklin, NC
Destination: Mile 132, just beyond Wesser Bald shelter

Journal Story: Rolled into NOC,stayed 3hrs doing town stuff including a shower w hot water! Made it to sassafras shelter

sunrise on Cheoha Bald was beautiful. 20 tough, long miles. Tonight a meal and a bed in a room at Fontana and a full day off tomorrow. A quick summary.....164.3 miles in 11 days, about 40,000 ft of ascent and 40,000 of descent at an average of 9% grade. I definitely am taking a zero tomorrow!
perfect! Rained while I was indoors looking out! Lotta good food, conversation with other hikers and lots of time off my feet!

Dense forest, spent a few hours getting up 5000ish and then the trail became very, well, walkable! Spent half the day hiking with Lobster and after lunch, really moved with Wrong Way. A day of food and rest probably helped too. Partly sunny and cool. The privy at the shelter had been torn down and several ATC volunteers, a Ridge Runner(paid to patrol the trail) and a forest service guy all stayed at the shelter because a helicopter was making 15 drops in the morning of all the materials for  making a new one. The amount of work these folks do, for free, for the love of this trail, is amazing. Really makes me pay close attention to Leave No Trace policies.Friggin cold again at night, but the tent is doing it’s job of keeping me dry and warm. If anyone finds a tent site that’s actually flat... lemme know.

More rugged today. Although it started off cold, down to one layer after a couple of hours. Ended early, about 4ish, ate a ton of food and lots of hot tea. The shelters in the smokies have fireplaces inside and tarps as the 4th wall and we have had great fires the last 2 nights to take away the chill. A treat for sure.I have met many former military folks on the trail. Army, Air Force and several Marines Inevitably, whenever I introduced myself as TJ and said I had no trail name yet, the Marines said “you gotta be Tijuana”. I guess Californians and the Marines that train there have used TJ as a nickname for Tijuana for a long time. I kept saying no, doesn’t feel right, etc... But after the last guy, Mr. President, I finally said what the hell and started using Tijuana.

Wow! Gorgeous sunrise at the tallest point on the AT! Hiked in the dark for a couple of hours to get to 6612 ft and a weird observation deck to witness the sunrise with a handful of other hikers that got up early too. Lotsa colors, loved watching the shadows form over the mountains below. Very cool and of course my ifotos don’t do it justice. Ten miles to a packed trailhead and parking lot on the Tennessee/NC borderline.  It is definitely spring break. Hordes of tourists, endless kids, cars everywhere. Hitched a ride with a brit on driving vacation into Gatlinburg and another huge shock. DollyWood! Really? Anyhow food, laundry, shower and resupply remain the same.Finally, thanks so much for the great comments and support! I can’t believe all this rambling gibberish actually makes any sense anyone. Back to the Smokies!  Tijuana

noon start. Packed trail head again. Crowds .thinned after 5ish miles. Good weather, easy day.And I stand very corrected about my smart ass attitude about Dolly. According to a variety of local folks she has been a long time, upstanding citizen and was amazing during and recovering from disastrous recent Gatlinburg fire. So.... !Que Viva Dolly!
Long, hard day. Pushed Hard to avoid predicted night and morning downpours. It did, and I was thrilled to be in a bunkhouse with a wood stove.

Left about 11 am, still raining a bit and some sleet as I climbed. Pushed hard to get to shelter before dark and just made it. The skies cleared and the temperature dropped fast to upper teens. Very uncomfortable night, couldn’t stay warm, constantly adjusting to get a few more degrees of comfort. Got up early and got going.... not fun.
Took 2hours of hard hiking to finally warm up, rest of day was fine. The Laughing Heart Hostel was literally one step off the trail I Hot Springs. Great people comfy bunk.
Got treated like royalty by the NC branch of the family. Soaked our bones, stuffed our faces and laughed our asses off! ThankYou!
Long day, still felt a bit tired, stayed at a nice, quiet hostel after 17 miles
Rain thru the morning.
Stunning sunrise, clouded valleys, mist rising up the ridges. Beautiful. Clean up, buy food, pack up, onward manana.
A bit of rain during the day. Made it to the shelter, filtered water, made dinner and then it really started raining! Slept great!

Wet, muddy climb up Roan. Seemed to rain or drip all day. At least it was warm enough to wear shorts as long as I was moving. In clouds all the way up, no views. I was surprised that it was a small, enclosed cabin with a door! It was nice to cook inside out of the weather.

Going down the mountain was muddy, very slippery and treacherous. After a few hours of sun, the mud firmed up a bit. The last several miles included long climbs and descents over two balds. Don’t know why, but I finally felt really good and was able to move well for the entire stretch.
Got to mount harbor hostel in the afternoon and was able to get cleaned up and organized fast. This is a clean, friendly, well thought out place. Very friendly and helpful owners. Can’t wait for the breakfast tomorrow!
Late start after a fabulous breakfast at the hostel. Hot day, waterfalls, dry trails made for better hiking than off of roan mtn.
Laurel Falls was beautiful and refreshing on a hot day. Pond Mtn damn near put me in an early grave, big climb at the end of the day.
Destination: Boots Off Hostel, near Hampton, TN

Journal Story: Really lucked out with weather. It was supposed to rain at several points during the day, but never really did. Ended up hiking til about 9ish with another guy for a 30 mile day. Lighting and thunder show while in tent failed to produce rain, but put me to sleep almost immediately!
Start location: Boots Off Hostel, near Hampton, TN

Journal Story: Entered Virginia and dropped into Damascus and the Woodchuck Hostel. Easy living and accessible supplies for someone who gets around by walking.
Nice town, good food, great hostel. Definitely fattened up a bit while here.
Tough town to leave. Showers climbing out of town didn’t make it any easier. Fabulous sunset, lousy night of sleep.
Grayson ponies always lookin for a handout!
steady day ending at the mousiest shelter to date. I tented away from the shelter!

10 very fast ones to make an early shuttle time from HQ to Marion. It was worth the huffing and puffing. I got a cheap motel room and the local enchiladas y tamales were pretty damn good, all things considered. Now we have 2 days of thunderstorms and possible tornadoes. I’m staying put til that stuff passes.

A steady 20 that ended at a nice shelter full of mice. They didn’t even pretend to wait til dark, just started running about while we watched from a picnic table. Needless to say, I tented a good bit away from the shelter.

Quick 11, mid day, in the rain, with a very light pack and new shoes! Retired the last pair with at least 550 miles on ‘em. Go brooks calderas! Hmmmm, light pack, new shoes.... what the @#$& is going on here?

Can a bald retiree thru hiking the AT have a spring break? Why the hell not? My sweetheart arrived with a boat load of replacement gear and a big, fat care package full of great trail treats from our daughter! Couldn’t get any better, right? Wrong.I drove a car! I wore cotton clothes. I don’t reek of sweat, smoke, mud, shelter grime or mold! I haven’t been attacked by a rhododendron for days! I am dry! I carry things in my hands, not on my back. On the 4th day of spring break, I actually felt full after a meal.... for more than an hour!And while WiFi is at my fingertips, I want to say thanks, again, to all of you for the support and encouragement.
Beautiful, sunny day hike (8 miles rt) to the famed hanging rock with my Sweetie! Great views. Fotos soon.
By far and away, the hardest thing I’ve done on this hike is give Betsy one last hug and walk into the woods.
Long day, good weather, no mice in the shelter!

Good Day, dry trails, great lunch at Brushy Mtn Outpost and a long afternoon to get to Lickskillet. Tomorrow’s forecast: 100% chance of rain, and thunder showers. I think I’ll have a second cup of coffee before heading into the storm tomorrow morning!Oh yeah, we passed the 600 mile “marker today! We means Legend and his great dog, Jasper
Showered, rained, or poured off and on all day. I ate and napped.
Good trail conditions and weather lead to good miles. Other hikers are starting to see bears. So far, all I’ve seen is scat!
Standard town stop. Shovel in as many calories as possible, grocery store, laundry, shower, charge phone and stay the hell off my feet!
Flopped down and tented near a tiny spring, up on a ridge,in the middle of the woods, with Helluva. He’s hauling a carbon guitar and teaching himself to play while on trail.
Very friggin’ hot and lots of climbing. Managed to get up on a ridge for a cooler night in the tent. Good sunset!
Definitely getting in some early exposure to heat and humidity. Kickin’ my *##!

The redo on Mcafee Knob wasn’t the same w/o Betsy. Tinkers Cliffs was very cool but got chased off by thunder and lightening. It finally caught me a couple hours later and got drenched for 30 min and swam down the trails in rivers of mud and debris. One hour later it was hot and humid again. Made it to Daleville, late, w/o slippin’ and killing myself. Shower, Mexican food, pint of ice cream, bed... couldn’t have taken another step. Time for a zero.
Tired, beat up from the hump over Dragons Tooth, hunger and lousy weather kept me town resting.
Had a great breakfast at a diner and a slab of cake for dessert before heading out into the light rain. Ended up being a mostly dry day.
lots of views from overlooks on the Blue Ridge Parkway, which the trail crosses many times.
Pushed hard to make a noon ride into town. Resupplied at a great little grocery/hardware store and enjoyed the company of many other hikers at the only restaurant in town.
Good day for hiking.
Rocky and lots of climbing. Rain and howling wind at night. Couldn’t get my damn rain fly to  flap in the wind quietly, so not much sleep. :)
Damn fast 15 to glamping and fab food at a sprawling country brewery/campground called Devil’s Backbone.
Pushed thru rain to get off trail by 5:00, into town and on to a rest day.
News spread fast about an attack on 2 people on the AT approximately 300 miles south of here. An arrest was made and details coming out in the media.
Got down into the 30s, but managed to stay warm and sleep well even though I sent home some of the cold weather gear.
nice views, a camp store for lunch, and another cold night.
Stayed at a big car campground and ate at the lodge with a great group of hikers. See the foto!
Fabulous views of the Shenandoah Valley and lunch at Skyland Lodge.
Pushed hard, lots of descending and got in about 6 at a great hostel outside of Front Royal.

Dear Family and Friends,Thanks again for the nice notes, support and concern after the recent tragedy on the trail. But believe me, I am lucky to be leapfrogging, hiking with, tenting next to, elbowing in a shelter, eating dinner or breakfast with all kinds of great folks everyday. And all of them willing to lend a hand when needed. Chao!
snagged one last milkshake before hitching back to trail. Of course I get picked up by a massage therapist on the way to her job at a ritzy b&b!Hot one today

Tough heat, humidity, rugged, rocky, relentless up/down for 14 friggin miles. But hey, I ended the day with some great folks I met treating me to a hostel stay and dinner at a fab brewery with a view near the hostel. Thanks to Oregon, Pennsylvania and Vermont for lending 3 great guys to the trail!

Passed the 1000 mark. Paused for a moment of contemplation and celebration until driven on by hordes of flying insects! I think a pint of ice cream in town is a better way to celebrate. Fabulous weather today, cool,dry, breezy, perfect for hiking.Walked across the Shenandoah River to get to town.... gorgeous!Foto at the ATC headquarters manana, more town food and over the Potomac River I go.
left Harpers Ferry about noon and crossed the upper Potomac. Beautiful! Groomed flat path for a couple miles and at the end of the day, a Campground w a hot shower!
Some good views in the morning and then hammered by thunderstorms and lightning in the afternoon! Mud.
perfectly set up and well maintained, plus there is swing and a sundial too!
Whoa! The Doyle Hotel has a great old time feel, is in terrible condition, and has lousy hygiene.
Got the tent up before the rain storm.
just got hammered for hours, one rainstorm after another. However, there was leftover pizza at the shelter.... spectacular!

I know I’m repeating myself, but more rain storms. The trail is either a stream or a pond at all times. However, I was very lucky to be hosted by simply wonderful folks who opened their home to me. Clean, dry, warm, well fed and in a real bed!
Thanks to my wonderful hosts, I was able to get lots of little chores done. I even got a fabulous hair cut at the famous barbershop.

Finally! Goodbye Pennsylvania! Fabulous people, horrific, rocky, swampy trails that seemed to go on forever! I was hit with lightning, rain, showers, sideways rain, thunderstorms, hailed on, and sideswiped by a tornado that touched down west of the ridge I was damn near blown off.
Wonderful trail magic feast on the side of a dirt road the trail crosses. It was set up by the fine families of two thru hikers. Excellent.
ended the day with feet up on the porch of horlers general store, eating ice cream, waiting for Betsy to pick me up!
Zero with my sweetheart!
Saw the nyc skyline from the trail for the first time today and crossed 1400
we had a group of 6 that had the whole state park to ourselves... very nice!Many thanks to all for the bday wishes , continued support, and the link for trail mileage!
Lots of rain, cool temps, breezy. Stopped early to get dry and warm.
Started in GA on March 14, hiked into CT on June 14! Very exciting for me and totally underwhelming for the hikers I was with at the time. I can’t believe I just hiked 1460 miles to get home to ct!
Campsite with a covered cooking pavilion. Tented under it to stay outta the rain. Very nice!
Rain.
That felt good. Think I’ll do another.
And three’s a charm!

Excellent hiking day. The trail was relatively dry, terrain manageable, partly cloudy, low humidity and a great breeze keeping the bugs off. It ended in dalton and tenting in the grassy backyard of a hiker friendly local.
Rained out. Stopped to stay dry, enjoy a nice grocery, bakery and restaurant.

Wow! GB treats hikers well. Tented behind the community center and allowed full access for showering, charging and water. Grocery, Mexican food, fast food and breakfast within walking distance!Oh yeah.... crossed into Massachusetts today!
great views!
rain storms
Mud. Long stretches of mud.
Mud and muck for a couple hours, then much drier up and down Stratton. Jean the fire tower caretaker was kind and full of good info. The shelter was wonderful and the pond beautiful.
Hello again Manchester. Sure missing Ana y Cochise!
Couple of downpours, little thunder, not bad in the pm.
Lotsa daylight and dry trails make miles.
Trail magic delivered today, in person, by Betsy and Emily! Doesn’t get any better!
Wonderful sunset, sunrise and fab views from a cabin on top of a mtn.
Tented in town in a friendly backyard. Watched young folks jumping off the bridge into the White River to celebrate the 4th! Unfortunately, I slept thru the fireworks later that night.
Sunset.... stars galore all night.... and sunrise, all from the smarts mtn firetower.
moosilauke and kinsman are friggin rugged!
And here come the Whites’!
Franconia ridge, rugged, gnarly, beautiful views and chased off by thunderstorms. Grateful for a night in a hut.
Rain off and on. Gorgeous views at times
Great views and hiking to share with Nico on his return to the Whites! And hey, a bowl of chili at the top of Washington was nice too!
8 tough miles that just disappeared with good stories told well! Thanks again Nico!
Very steep, treacherous all day with stunning views of the presidential range. Gracias a Dios it was great weather too!
Yes! I’m trashed and desperately need zeros!
Great views and lotsa muddy mountain bogs.
Went thru the famous “Mahoosuc Notch” today. Very cool and challenging scramble. Called the toughest mile on the entire AT. Thought my arms were gonna fall off!
Half day and then hitched a ride to the Human Nature Hostel. A “WOW!” kinda place. Look it up and then watch an episode of Naked and Afraid on the Discovery Channel featuring the owner!
wow! Rangely is a nice Village. Saw my first pontoon plane

Check out the canoe ferry. It’s like Uber, only I had to whistle real loud, so the dogs across the river would bark at the ferrylady, and then she looked over at us and waved and proceeded to come and pick us up. Better than Uber!
